      <<<<<<< HEAD:docs/reference/STdiff_volcano.html

      STdiff_volcano: Generates volcano plots from STdiff results

      STdiff_volcano.Rd

      Generates volcano plots of differential expression results from STdiff

      STdiff_volcano(
=======

      bulk_pca: Performs PCA on "bulk" spatial array

      bulk_pca.Rd

      Perform and plot a PCA of simulated bulk RNA-Seq from spatial transcriptomics data.

      Usage

      bulk_pca(
>>>>>>> 3db90f5bf04af3fb4f198dfb630dd1b87ad08ae2:docs/reference/bulk_pca.html
  x = NULL,
  samples = NULL,
  clusters = NULL,
  pval_thr = 0.05,
  color_pal = NULL
)

      Arguments

      x
      <<<<<<< HEAD:docs/reference/STdiff_volcano.html

      the output of STdiff

      samples

      samples to create plots

      clusters

      names of the clusters to generate comparisons

      pval_thr

      the p-value threshold to color genes with differential expression

      color_pal

      the palette to color genes by significance

      Value

      a list of ggplot objects

      Details

      The function generated volcano plots (p-value vs. log-fold change) for genes tested with STdiff. Colors can be customized to show significance from spatial and non-spatial models

      Contents

      =======

      an STList.

      clinvar

      a string indicating the name of the variable in the clinical data.

      color_pal

      a string of a color palette from khroma or RColorBrewer, or a vector with colors with enough elements to plot categories.

      tr_method

      one of 'log' or 'voom'. The data transformation to use.

      ptsize,

      a number specifying the size of the points. Passed to size aesthetic.

      Details

      This function takes an STList, and optionally the name of a clinical or sample-associated variable, and performs PCA on simulated bulk RNA-Seq from ST data. The counts are simulated by summing all counts from an array for each gene.

      Examples

      # In this example, melanoma is an STList.
# bulk_pca(melanoma, clinvar='gender')
